content: If you would like to add documentation to the Picotron Wiki, please create a pull request.
As of writing this, this is a sole person documentation project.
camera() allows for you to set the relative 0,0 of all graphical operations.
Sets a player object to be in the middle of the screen
--set the player to be in the middle of the screen
This can be paired with `mid()` to clamp it to the viewable area, e.g: the map.
Returns the previous camera's x,y positions.
`cp` copies the file or folder from `src_p` to the location `dest_p`.
If `dest_p` is a file, it overwrites the file.
The path to the source file/folder
Path to a folder/file to replace
If src is nil > "could not resolve source path"
If dest is nil > "could not resolve destination path"
If using a protocol (e.g: `bbs://`) > "can not write to {protocol you attempted}://"
fstat of the source fails > "could not read source location"
copying a folder inside of itself > "can not copy inside self"
copying `/` inside of itself > "can not copy /"
`create_process` runs a process, `prog_name_p`, with optional env data patched in through `[env_patch]`;
This can be done to package multiple pieces of software into one, alongside allowing for multi-process software.
The filepath to the file of which to create a process from.
This is typically a picotron cartridge or a `.lua` file.
This allows you to patch environmental information to the process in the form of a table.
This creates a process, running `app.p64` where `app.p64` prints the text that was fed into it.
When this process runs `env()`, it contains the argument `text`.
Sandboxed apps can only create processes of:
* files stored within the sandboxed app
All apps run through this are also sandboxed
This function returns the process id of the created process & an error string.
If the process created is a process that they cannot create > nil, "sandboxed process can not create_process()"
If the process creates more than 20 processes in a single minute > return nil, "sandboxed process can not create_process() more than 20 / minute"
`get_spr` returns the sprite information of the sprite at `index`.
The sprite index of which you want the information
This returns the `userdata u8` graphical data of the sprite at sprite `index`.
`map` draws a map, either through picotron system or legacy pico-8 method
The map data in the datatype `userdata`
If `ud` is not in the datatype `userdata`, it follows the legacy Pico-8 format.
Extra arguments that are sent through to the system _draw_map function.
This function does not return anything
The legacy Pico-8 system is added for legacy support and an alternative way to use maps.
The column location of the map cell in the upper left corner of the region to draw, where 0 is the leftmost column.
The row location of the map cell in the upper left corner of the region to draw, where 0 is the topmost row.
The x coordinate of the screen to place the upper left corner.
The y coordinate of the screen to place the upper left corner.
The number of map cells wide in the region to draw.
The number of map cells tall in the region to draw.
If specified, only draw sprites that have flags set for every bit in this value (a bitfield). The default is 0 (draw all sprites).
This function does not return anything
`memmap` allows you to write a 4k (`0x1000`) userdata, `ud` to an address, `addr` in memory
The userdata that is mapped into memory
The address to map the userdata into
Mapping to address `0x100000` automatically unmaps the loaded map data & replacing the loaded map in memory with `ud`.
> Presuming that it's the offset in either memory in the userdata
> Presuming that it's the length of the userdata
`mkdir` creates a new directory (empty folder) at the path `p`
This does not support protocols (e.g: bbs://)
The path for the new directory
This function returns an error in the form of a string if the function fails.
`mv` moves the file or folder from `src_p` to `dest_p`.
The path to the source file/folder
Path to a folder to put the source file/folder into
If src is nil > "could not resolve source path"
If dest is nil > "could not resolve destination path"
If using a protocol (e.g: `bbs://`) > "can not write to {protocol you attempted}://"
More returns are for other failures, unknown.
`pid` returns the process id of the process calling it.
This is useful for communication between processes
Using the filenav with the intention to save a file.
open_with = pid(), --shows the id of the process that opened it
Documentation on all of functions in the Picotron API
`rm` deletes `f0`, a file or directory (including all of the directory's contents).
Attempting to delete `/desktop/host` just causes the Host OS to unmount, rather than deleting the folder and contents.
The path to the file or directory to delete
Returns something, unknown what it returns
`send_message` allows you to communicate with other processes.
This is useful for communication between processes
The process ID of which to send the message to
The message, a table, to send to the process `proc_id`.
A message must have the key `event`, being a string that is sent to the process as its event.
This can be any arbritrary string - handled by the process that receives it.
By setting `[response]` to `true`, it causes the function to stall the entire program until it receives a response from the other process.
Note that blocking in this way can be quite slow - it is intended to be used in situations where it is acceptable to skip a frame or two while waiting for a reply.
When `[response]` is a function, the event handler of the receiving process can reply with another message that is handled by that function.
When reply is true, send_message blocks until the process responds with a reply. For example, paste the following in to terminal to set up a headless process that responds to "get_id" messages:
A unique id can be fetched from this process with:
The true argument for `[response]` causes the message to be blocking - waiting for the response from `pid2`, being the data including the `id` it requests.
Sandboxed processes can send messages to:
* "broadcast" *if* it has a contained event of `set_palette`
This function returns nothing, unless you have a response, where it instead returns the response of the event.
`set_spr` adds or removes a sprite at a set index.
The index of the sprite you're modifying in the spritesheet.
The sprite data to set in sprite `index`, form of a `userdata u8`.
The flag information to be set for sprite `index`, defaults to 0
This function does not return anything
`sspr` draws a sprite, similar to [`spr()`](/functions/spr/main.md), but allows you to also resize the sprite.
This is scaling sprites, e.g: zoom
Sprite index from the spritesheet, or a `userdata u8` piece of data - this is what is drawn.
The coordinates of where to draw the sprite
Flips the sprite on their respective axis
Draw a sprite from sprite index 0 to position (0,0)
Draw a sprite from a `userdata u8` to position (0,0)
`sspr` draws a sprite, similar to [`spr()`](/functions/spr/main.md), but allows you to also resize the sprite.
This is scaling sprites, e.g: zoom
Sprite index from the spritesheet, or a `userdata u8` piece of data - this is what is drawn.
The coordinates of what is treated as the top left of `sprite`, allowing you to add offsets
The width & height of `sprite` - allows you to crop the sprite.
Where you want the sprite to be drawn on the screen
Optional, defaults to the proportions of the sprite
`sprite` will be drawn rescaled to match the proportions of `[dx],[dy]`.
Flips the sprite on their respective axis
set_draw_target(mapUD) --all graphical operations now go to the map userdata
set_draw_target() --return graphical operations to the window/screen
--mapwidth,mapheight is the proportions of the map
--x,y is where to draw the map
`store` allows you to store files, typically used for save files by storing tables in the `pod` file format.
The location you want to store a file at, e.g: `/appdata/mypod.pod`
The file data, e.g: a table for a `.pod` file.
Optional metadata of the file, e.g: `{mymetadatavalue="grapes"}`
This function does not return anything
`store_metadata` stores metadata, `meta`, at a file or directory, `filename`, merging with the original metadata.
The path to the file or directory to store metadata in
The metadata to store in the file or directory
This function does not return anything
Ability to remove metadata items from the pre-existing metadata
this is the only way to release mapped userdata for collection
e.g. memmapping a userdata over an old one is not sufficient to free it for collection
The userdata that is unmapped from memory
The address to unmap the userdata from
Length of the userdata to unmap, defaults to the full userdata length
This function does not return anything
This is a short guide designed to teach you to create a simple game on a grid.
To begin, you should draw the following sprites:
Do this through the GFX Editor in `gfx/0.gfx`, and have all sprites the same size (e.g: 16x16).
You will need the map that your player will be on, this can be done with the map editor at `map/0.map`.
Using the ground tiles and solid tiles, draw out the terrain.
In your `main.lua` is the main code for your cartridge. This is called when your cartridge is run, allowing you to import other `lua` files and create the basis of your game.

To create the main loop, you can create the `_init`, `_update` and `_draw` functions - these are called on startup, every frame, and when a draw is called (less frequent than `_update` if there's lag) respectively.
You will want to have a player variable, a table, and something to draw the player to the screen. Treat the player's positioning as fixed to the grid.
You can now access the player with stuff like `player.x`, `player.y` and `player.sprite`.
Your update loop can be ignored for now.
Your draw loop can draw the screen.
The screen will consist of the map and the sprite.
You can draw the map with [`map`](/functions/map/main.md) and draw the sprite with [`spr`](/functions/spr/main.md).
You will need to call `cls()` at the beginning of the draw function - this will clear the screen and avoid drawing ontop of the previous frame continuously.
By multiplying it by 16, it applies it to a grid where each tile is 16x16. Replace `16` with your custom size if you have a different proportion - this does not affect anything else.
By running this, you will now see the player at (2,2) but you cannot interact with the player.
Using the `_update` loop, you can add movement to the player.
This can be done with the `btnp` function, which detects button presses every 4 frames.
Create your update loop as such
This will move the player left when you press left on the DPAD or analog joystick (left arrow key)
Adding the following adds the other directions.
This allows you to have full movement control of the player.
If you run it now, it allows you to move along the grid for your game - though, it doesn't include collisions and stop you from leaving the map.
Within Picotron Lua, you can also make use of inline code to clean the functions as seen:
You can add collisions using `mget` by checking if the tile the player wants to move to is a solid tile or not.
You can set this up in the update loop by creating a temporary x,y position that checks the collision before setting the player's true position.
This craetes an x,y identical to the player's position at the start of the function.
Now, instead of applying the movements to player.x,player.y, you apply it to nx,ny
This treats tile `1` as a tile the player can walk ontop of & through.
If the tile that the player tries to enter is not tile `1`, it ignores the collision.
You can upgrade the tile system (checking collisions) with tables.
Creating a lookup table with a table allows you to refer to this with the tile the player moves into.
Create a tile registry is as such:
Using `[index]`, it allows you to write an index into it, with a `true` value indicating that it is walkable.
You do not need to add `[2]=false` or any other solid tile to this as such as it will default to being seen as false.
Checking the collision is now seen as such:
If `walkableTiles[tile]` is not set, this fails - indicating that it is solid.
If it is set, it indicates that it is walkable, and allows the player to walk through the tile.
This tile system can be continued for any arbritrary purpose, e.g: if you want another type of tile.
You can check this in the same way that you checked collisions before, using the `waterTiles` lookup table alongside the `walkableTiles` lookup table
You now have a simple player controller and a simple game loop, you can build on top of this yourself (or with any following guides) to create a larger game!
// Open-access web build for testing (became unavailable at 0.1)
Architecture	// File system, system events, memory mapping, wm
GFX Pipeline	// Colour tables, draw state
API	// Based on Lua 5.4, compatible w/ PICO-8 where possible
CPU	// Find costs that roughly match slowest hosts
** offline for now, but will come back later in some form
Editors	// Code, Pixels, Maps, Synth Designer, Tracker
Desktop	// Run window-based programs, file management gui
HTTP GET	// From local apps and exports only; not BBS carts
BBS Integration	// Submit carts to a sub-forum, load # directly from bbs
Sandboxing	// Safe to run untrusted carts without exposing Picotron drive
HTML Exporter	// .wasm runtime + bundled cartridge, licensed similar to P8
Binary Exporters	// Windows, Mac, Linux -- includes desktop export
bbs://	// [in 0.1.1e] Cross-platform bbs access; handles caching / offline access
Tooltray	// [in 0.1.1e] Install widgets into the tooltray that can run sandboxed
UDP / TCP sockets	// For binaries / exports
GFX API	// rrect, P8SCII outline / underline
Headless Programs	// interactive terminal apps, background processes
Spritesheet Importer	// load from png / p8
Anywhen	// Fetch files and directory listings from any point in time
File System	// sandboxing, mounting, robustness improvements
Unsaved Changes	// monitor at the cart / file level and confirm overwrites etc
Events	// non-blocking fetch(), blocking send_message(), custom mainloops
Logins	// User can log in with bbs account, apps can read username
podnet://	// User-wise public storage that can be used by sandboxed apps
flp.io	// Bucket naming service; allows publishing podnet websites
Cart switching	// BBS carts can load & run other BBS carts
Video Modes	// Support for extra fullscreen video modes
Native Windows	// Export carts that run directly in a native host window
BBS highscores	// Submit scores + extra data while logged in
Websockets	// For exports [and bbs carts] on all platforms
Log Navigation	// Browse logs by category: notifications, errors, system crash etc
Gui Builder	// Gui card editor and data format integrated with create_gui
Libraries	// Standard fonts, instruments, fill patterns, palettes
Stickers	// A general tagging and bookmarking scheme (experimental)
Tool Improvements	// Miscelaneous features for bundled tools & accessories
PFX6416 Features	// pcm instrument type, sfx instruments, channel-fx envelope control
// Exported runtime licensing is TBD, but the focus will be on allowing cart authors to
// implement additional platform support or custom features for their own projects.

Picotron is a Fantasy Workstation: a self-contained creative environment built for imaginary hardware. Create and share cute Lua apps that can run on the Picotron desktop, be shared as cartridge files, or exported as stand-alone HTML and binary distributables.

Picotron comes with a 480x270 64-colour display, which can also run at 240x135 or 160x90 and with custom palettes in fullscreen mode. The built-in graphics api gives versatile low-level access to the display, with features like 8x8 fill patterns, palette swapping and blending, stencil bits and tline3d for rasterizing perspective correct textures.

Picotron uses a virtual filesystem that only exposes parts of your host system as needed. All files inside Picotron are in a special format (POD: Picotron Object Data) that allows Lua tables to be directly stored and fetched from disk. Storing data like save games and level data is simple: bundle everything into a Lua table and store() it as a pod.

All of the audio in Picotron is generated in realtime by a purpose-built 64-node, 16 channel synthesizer called PFX6416. Nodes can either generate a signal from a wavetable, or modify it using FM/RING modulation, delay, HP/LP resonant filters and wave-shaping. Instruments and music/tracker data in Picotron are extremely tiny on disk; a piece of music with custom instrument design can be stored in 5~20k.

Picotron uses a separate (slightly modified) Lua 5.4 vm per "process", and virtual cpu is divided up between processes for a maximum of 8M vm instructions per second. This means that Picotron cartridges can run at a consistent speed across varying platforms; if it runs ok on a high-end desktop machine, it will look roughly the same running under web on an old netbook.

Applications, projects and distributable bundles are all the same type of thing in Picotron: a cartridge. Each cartridge acts like a regular folder and contains all of the source files and resources needed to run the program. On the host system it is stored as a single git-friendly text file (.p64: any size that fits in ram), or a shareable png format (.p64.png: max 256k of ROM data).

Picotron comes with a cute desktop interface featuring tabbed workspaces and a fold-out tooltray that is accessible from any workspace. The tooltray acts as a second desktop for handy access to frequently used files and widgets. Files can also be dropped on top of each other to form tidy stacks that are shuffleable with the mousewheel.

Use the built-in editors or create your own! The included editors for code, graphics, tile maps, music and sound effects are themselves all made in Picotron and use standard /system/lib libraries for handling things like unlimited undo stacks, gui, and file management.
Make your own live wallpapers, screensavers, icons, widgets, and set up workflows just the way you like! Or have a look around the BBS to see what other cartridge authors are up to.

Picotron is built on tightly integrated, flexible graphics and audio pipelines that can happily run on low powered host machines and web. They each come with a simple-to-use API for handling common things like drawing a colour-swapped sprite or triggering a sound effect, but the underlying data and machine state is all exposed in virtual RAM, offering a myriad of possibilities for those willing to venture down the rabbithole.
Picotron 0.2 is still new, but has a relatively complete API, binary and HTML exporters and BBS cartridge browsing. See the roadmap for future plans:
A likely futile attempt to support the documentation of [Picotron](https://www.lexaloffle.com/picotron.php).
